sites.tags: pre-roman, roman, sulis minerva, spring, classical
sites.description: An early Roman period temple set around a natural spring with an adjoining bath complex. There is some evidence to suggest that the spring had some ritual significance prior to the Roman structure, it has also been shown that the ritual use of the site continued strongly into the 4th Century with continued deposition of coins, defixiones, and modifications to the temple itself. Aquae Sulis is unique in that it is one of the few sites we have a contemporary reference to in Solinus, De Mirabilibus Mundi, Capitula XXIIII.

sites.description: We know the temple was destroyed sometime in the 2nd Century. The latest coin issue was dated to 161 - 180 and there is evidence of burnt roof tiles and timbers, however, there is evidence of continued use as a burial ground. If the suspected burial just to the west is to be included we can push it's use to the 6th or 7th Century.

sites.description: The earliest ritual activity recorded at Chelmsford begins in 60 AD and shows continuous activity until the early 5th. The latest coin issue found on the site dates from 388 - 402 AD with the distinct possibility of later activity. The sites demise is likely connected to the end of the Roman town in which it sat to the east. Wickenden suggests a dedication to Mars.

sites.description: A site with two temples, the earlier is described as a circular shrine, the later is a square temple. Located on the edge of a ridge beside the river Ock. For the later square temple (Frilford 2), Lewis (1966) suggests a chronology beginning in the later 1st CE, annexes were added in the late 3rd CE and early 4th CE, and fell into 'decay' at some point in the 5th CE.

Wedlake suggests that the initial shrine was constructed soon after 69 CE and no later than 210 CE, the site was built up over time and possibly re-used as a church and homestead while a small part of it was used for worship until around 370 CE.

sites.description:
A probable Romano-British temple of uncertain date, the site has been known since the 50s when it was observed as a cropmark (King, Soffe, 1983). The site consists of two concentric masonry foundations (17.5m x 16m) and (8.5, x 7.5m) enclosing a slightly off-centre rectangle which has been interpreted as a possible foundation of a plinth, altar, statue, or else a pool or well. The entrance is more than likely on the east side, though this is not clear from aerial photography.

The site (SU 8090 0644) overlooks a nearby stream at the bottom of a gentle slope to the east. Just outside the temple between itself and the river is a large circular structure with a large central depression 21m in diameter and an encircling ditch of 31m in diameter. Rudling postulates an earlier shrine or location for depositions.

No excavation has been carried out so the date can only be suggested from surface level finds. The earliest finds are Late iron age pottery and coins (Rudling, 2008). The bulk of pottery is late first and second centuries, but one sherd may be third or fourth century (King, Soffe, 1983).

sites.description: Richborough Castle began as a temporary military camp for Plautius' invasion force in 43 AD, the only settlement prior to this was an Iron Age farmstead that was abandoned around 100 BC. At the end of the first century AD timber structures were cleared away and the site became a more permanent civilian settlement with an associated port. In the late third century AD the site again became a military establishment, the central part of the town was levelled and the monument constructed to celebrate the conquest of Britain was converted into a signal station, this signal station was eventually levelled to construct a shore fort. Around this time, it is suggested that the two Roman-Celtic temples to the south were constructed. By the end of the fourth century the fort was no longer garrisoned by regular troops, though the fort continued to be used as a settlement into the fifth century where it is noted in the Notitia Dignitatum. Around this time the temples would have already collapsed but continued to be used as two deposits were found inserted into the wall, it is around this same time that the proposed church associated with the baptismal font was constructed. It is unsure when these structures stopped being used but the fort was abandoned during the later fifth and sixth centuries.

sites.description: A square Romano-Celtic type temple four-miles north east of Oxford and built on top of a hill. First referred to in 1841 by Hursey, who mentions traces of buildings at the site. Though the Saxon charter of Eaton (904 CE) may refer to the site as faga flora (coloured floor), referencing mosaics, but this not certain. Excavations in 1952 revealed a two-period temple, the earlier of which was dated to the 1st century CE, less is known about the second phase but it was probably constructed in the mid 2nd century CE. Iron Age occupation at the site has been shown but this is not necessarily continuous and no structure is known.

sites.description:
A large octagonal building surrounded by what appears to be an ambulatory was constructed sometime after 120 CE on the site of the modern Old Bailey building. Prior to this the site appears to have been the centre of the glass working industry in Roman London.

The structure has been interpreted as a Romano-Celtic temple, though not much more is known and Perring and Brigham now prefer to interpret it as a 'secular' structure.

sites.description: A small classical temple built just to the west of the first forum in the east of Roman London, built at the same time, around 75 CE. The temple lay roughly 10 metres west, on the outside of the forum, now under the building between Lombard St and Bell Inn Yard. The temple was short lived and was demolished while the second, much larger forum was being constructed around 100 CE - 130 CE. No new temple was built to replace it.

sites.description:
A shrine is suggested to have been somewhere under the modern Goldsmith's Hall. Masonry foundations are reported to have been recorded there, and a probably 2nd CE altar with an image identified as Diana was found there.

It's also notable that the site is only roughly 300 metres north-west of the two Gresham Street temples.

sites.description:
A Romano-Celtic temple located in the east of modern day Greenwich Park. The site is located on a hill-top which would of been along Watling Street before it went on to Roman London. The site had an incomplete inscription dedicating the temple to the Imperial Divinities, as well as a roof tile with the London procurial stamp, suggesting that the temple was built on imperial order.

There are associated buildings such as a guest house, as well as a free standing statue of Diana Venatrix.

sites.location: England, London, Peter's Hill and Salvation Army Headquarters
sites.description:
Two temples were constructed alongside the riverside wall (roughly modern Castle Baynards St). One, under the south-east quadrant of the Salvation Army International HQ building, and the other just to the west on Peter's Hill. The two temples were built not long after much of the complex appears to have been demolished for refurbishment and to sure-up the riverside wall. 

It appears that the temples may have never been actually completed. Due to the dating of dendrochronology allowing us to establish the beginning of construction so tightly (spring to summer 294 CE), it has been suggested the construction was initiated by Carausius as a project to promote his authority during the Carusian Revolt and that the project was never finished due to the assassination of his successor Allectus and the re-conquest of Britain in 296 CE.

Bradley and Butler have suggested that the temples may be a kind of 'successor' to the earlier monumental apses which had been destroyed earlier and are roughly in the same location. They have also suggested that these apses were temples or shrines to Jupiter and Isis, so these later temples may have been intended to be dedicated to the same deities.

sites.location: England, London, Hankey Place Gardens, 20 Pilgrimage St
sites.description:
Two Romano-Celtic temples built in the later 2nd CE in a temenos that may have been pre-existing for a number of years. The north temple appears to have been dedicated to Mars Camulus early on, there is also another dedication relating to the imperial cult.  

During the 3rd CE the temples appear to have become much more popular, as a substantial structure was built to the south-east and is interpreted as a guest house, while to the north-east, an area with several plinths that could of been bases for statues has been interpreted as a gathering area.

The southern temple had been demolished some time in the later 3rd CE, while the northern one continued in use. It has been suggested that use of the northern temple didn't continue much longer after the late 4th CE as this seems to be when the dedication to Mars Camulus was deposited in a pit, but this isn't certain.

sites.description:
The Temple of Isis is only known from two inscriptions, the first is a jug from Tooley Street which read ''To London at the temple of Isis", and the second of which is an altar from the riverside wall at modern Cast Baynards St which records the refurbishment of the temple due to disrepair sometime around the 250s CE.

It is not known where the temple was or whether these inscriptions refer to a single site or two. Bradley and Butler suggest that one of the monumental arches that formed the riverside corners of the public complex in the south-west of Roman London may have been a temple or shrine to Isis, as they appear to have the space for a central statue. It is not suggested which it may have been, but the other may have been the Temple of Jupiter, recorded as being refurbished around the same place and time.

sites.description:
The Temple of Jupiter is a Temple that would of been located in the southwest quadrant of Roman London. We only know about it from an altar that recorded it's refurbishment after falling into a state of disrepair some time in the 250s CE. The altar was found re-used as building material in the riverside wall (which runs roughly along modern Castle Baynards St) which was constructed to sure-up the unstable land sometime around 270 CE.

This leads us to believe that it was probably part of the public precinct immediately to the north, Bradley and Butler suggest it may well have been one of the monumental apses that formed that the riverside corners of the complex and each appear to have had the space to hold a statue. It's not known which it might have been, but the other may have been the Temple of Isis, also recorded as being refurbished around the same time and place.

sites.description: A Roman villa structure that was built on the location of a Late Iron Age 'round house' of which later phases of construction appear to respect the curve of, despite the structure being long since gone. The 'round house' has been interpreted as a possible shrine due to its lack of domestic material and the reverence later builders seem to have shown it, despite no evidence of deposition activities. To the west of main building and in-line with the 'round house' is a square masonry structure also interpreted as a shrine. Probably first constructed in the third century, its foundations were widened in the northern and southern side at a later date, and subsequently an apsidal end was added to the west wall. Dating for this structure is uncertain as finds are minimal, but late Roman and early Saxon pottery of the late fourth or early fifth CE was found in a hollowed out area at the apsidal end of the structure suggesting activity continued until this date.

sites.description: A site just west of Chichester first excavated by Mitchell in 1832. Black suggests that there may have been a temple following a unusual layout of a central room with three connected rooms on either side, the main room had a c. 2m deep pit which showed evidence of burning. Just to the south-west traces of a theatre like structure, to the north-east was a timber palisade, possibly delimiting a temenos, to the west a possible mosaic was found, and to the north was a building witch Mitchell reports contained a coin of Honorius dating to 393 CE to 423 CE.

sites.description:
A site located south east of a Roman Villa, on a chalk hill overlooking fenland, lying on the boundary between Catevellauni and Iceni territory. The site is also north of, and uphill from a series of undated ring ditches. A trackway connectes the site with a nearby Iron Age settlement and burials, and later forms a direct link to the nearby villa.

The site is surrounded by a square enclosure, possibly of late iron age date, along with pottery (which Malim characterised as Late Iron Age and Belgic in nature) and other morphological similarities to LIA sites, Malim deems it reasonable to suggest a late prehistoric date for it's construction. But, the bulk of development appears to be late 1st or 2nd CE in date based on artifactual finds. A square double walled structure with circular foundations at the centre has been identified as a Romano-Celtic temple, though it is also suggested that the circular foundation shows similarities with sites of prehistoric date.  At some point a small structure was built within the main enclosure, and contained an inhumation burial, this was interpreted as a mausoleum of Roman date. A similar structure exists inside the circular foundations of the temple, though this was not fully excavated, it may be another mausoleum.

There is a lack of evidence for use of the site in the later 2nd - 4th century, but during the Anglo-Saxon period the site seems to have become used as a limited burial ground, with a number of burials and a post-hole structure being created in the main enclosure. These burials seem to have respected the temple, which Malim takes to indicate some continuity of belief, if not ritual activity.

sites.description: A classical podium style temple first excavated by Artis in the 1820s. The temple is surrounded by a series of houses which appear to have been constructed in the mid 3rd CE, which appear to be associated with the pottery industry. Thompson goes as far as suggesting that the settlement was created by a potter's guild using profits from the industry. Very little seems to be known about the chronology of the temple, but it seems likely the temple was constructed along with/for the settlement, which would suggest it was constructed some time in the mid 3rd CE.

sites.description: A flourishing late Iron Age settlement possible in an oppidum which became a major roadside settlement peaking in size during the 2nd CE. A Romano-Celtic temple has been identified by aerial photography, but, the unusual thing is that excavation in the late 60s and early 70s produced evidence of ritual activity (miniature votive axes, a spear, an iron rattle, fragments of a statue) about 250 metres north east of the temple. This led Stead and Rigby to suggest the presence of a second temple, though they did not identify a structure. Martyn et al seem to propose 'Building V' in the area of the votive finds as the second temple. This building seems to have been formed by a ring of upright timbers and appears to be surrounded by an enclosure (ditches 54, 56, 89). There are three internal pits in the structure but no dating evidence was found, the votive material and statue however, appear to range from the late 2nd to late 4th CE.

sites.description:
A square building (G) just to the east of the villa - on the highest part of the site. First identified during excavations in 1940, the large structure seems to have been of abnormal height, having a vaulted basement and a floor above that. The structure had a 'burial pit' 14ft deep in one corner, and while it did not have a temenos, it did have a cobbled courtyard containing the bones of young oxen. The structure appears to have had a black and white tessellated pavement and marble architectural features, such as architraves. It is suggested that the structure was a temple/mausoleum, based on comparisons with the Jordan Hill temple and the Temple of Janus in Autun, France. Scott suggests that the structure was used for grain storage at a later date, and was eventually demolished to provide building material for the nearby building (E) and other structures in the villa.

Note that Martyn et al suggest the temple is building F, this appears to be a mistake, Scott identifies building G as a temple.

sites.description: A mid 2nd CE Mausoleum built in a pre-existing enclosure in the crest of a hill overlooking a Roman villa. The Mausoleum appears identical to a Romano-Celtic temple, except beneath the central cella is a sarcophagi. The mausoleum appears to have been demolished in the mid 4th CE (probably for villa refurbishments), but, nearby in another pre-existing enclosure a small circular unmortared stone shrine was built. This shrine had a central pit containing deposits of spear heads, coins, and a young pig, outside the shrine were the butchered remains of an adult female goat. This shrine has been dated up until the late 4th CE.

sites.description: A large double ditched enclosure identified by aerial photography. It lies 5 km South-West of Cirencester on a spur at the head of a valley, further down the same valley isa spring which forms the source of the river Thames, overlooked by Trewsbury House hillfort. Only surveys have occurred so far, but the evidence found suggests a date range between the 1st CE and the late 4th CE, based on coins and pottery. The main reason for identifying this as a religious complex is its similarity in form to other sites such as Gosbecks, and Lee's Rest, as well as seven curse tablets recovered from the site. Two of these curse tablets reportedly mention Mercury.

sites.description: A rectangular masonry building and graves at the peak of Blaise Hill, an Iron Age Hillfort. The masonry building is believed to be of Roman date and interpreted as a temple, but a medieval chapel is also possible. The hillfort appears to have been intensively occupied during the Iron Age and into the Roman period, at the north-west foot of the hill there is evidence of small-scale Iron Age quarrying. In the 3rd century CE the remains of neonatal infants were interred in this quarry, before larger scale quarrying began later that century. A road was constructed that seems to connect the Hill Fort directly to the quarry.
